Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Controlling non-adiabatic reaction dynamics in solution: A window on the fundamental details of photochemical reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program in the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation, a group led by Professor Christopher Elles at the University of Kansas will study the ultrafast excited-state dynamics of color-changing photochromic molecular switches using time-resolved spectroscopy. Their research will probe the fundamental details that control the transformations of these molecules from one isomer to another following absorption of one or more photons. For example, different excitation schemes allow the dynamics through a conical intersection to be probed via different reaction pathways. Selectively controlling the dynamics for a range of model compounds will provide new insight on the non-adiabatic transitions that are ubiquitous in photochemistry and photophysics, in addition to providing detailed insight on the properties and limitations of the photochromic compounds that will be studied.

The results of these experiments will be widely applicable to understanding the dynamics of photon-initiated chemical reactions. In addition to the broad scientific impact, this five-year program also includes an educational outreach program that will train future science teachers to incorporate advanced topics into the high school curriculum. The educational program will engage undergraduate students enrolled in the UKanTeach teacher licensure program and work with them to develop novel lesson plans that will translate key concepts from the field of chemical dynamics into the classroom. Providing meaningful scientific training for prospective secondary science teachers will enhance the impact of the research and invigorate the high school curriculum with a direct connection to modern research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fundamental challenge in chemistry is to selectively control the making, breaking, and rearranging of bonds in a molecule. Selectively controlling reactions at the molecular scale not only opens the door to new technologies using molecular machines, motors, and switches, but also provides exquisite understanding of the fundamental details of chemical reactions in general. 

This project examined the reactions of technologically important photochromic molecules that reversibly change color upon irradiation with light. Studying the reactions of these 'molecular switches' provided new insight on the molecular-scale details that control chemical reactions. For example, excitation with ultrafast lasers that have pulse durations on the same timescale as the motions of the atoms reveals the pathway from the starting structure to the final structure of the molecule that occurs in only a few picoseconds, or a few millionths-of-a-millionth of a second. We used several techniques to monitor the changing structure of photochromic molecules during a reaction. The specific pathway that a molecule takes determines the rate of reaction and even the identity of the products that are formed.

We also found new ways to control the reactions of light-activated compounds using two laser pulses to sequentially excite the molecule. Initiating the reaction with one laser pulse converts only a small number of molecules from the colored form to a transparent form, but we showed that application of a second, time-delayed laser pulse gives the molecule an extra kick that increases the efficiency of the reaction. Not only do these experiments allow us to selectively control the outcome of the reaction, but also reveal new information about the highly excited molecules (after double excitation), and opens the door to using these highly excited states to initiate never-before-seen reactions of light-sensitive molecules. These new reaction pathways involve complicated relaxation channels that are difficult to study, but our measurements provide valuable benchmarks for comparison between experiment and theory. We worked with several theoretical chemistry groups to obtain a better understanding of the excited molecules, including the development of a new way to calculate one of the key experimental observables. This work will have lasting impact well beyond the compounds we studied, because the same principles will apply to a wide range of light-activated chemical reactions.

The broader impact of this work also includes an educational outreach effort that involved working with several aspiring high school science teachers in the undergraduate UKanTeach program at the University of Kansas to develop teaching modules that relate contemporary research topics to the high school curriculum. This work led to the collaborative development of lessons involving both pre-service and practicing science teachers, with a special emphasis on the development of lessons that incorporate concepts from the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). Research training for graduate and undergraduate students was also an important aspect of the project, including work by five doctoral research students, two masters degree candidates, and numerous undergraduate research students.
